Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Interactions of Ions with Polypeptides
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Paul S. Cremer at the Pennsylvania State University is exploring the roles that ions play in aqueous solutions containing organic molecules and polymers. Such research can have broad impact as ions influence an enormous variety of processes from allowing molecules to clump together or aggregate, to catalyze processes in cells, and even the length of time it takes to pickle a cucumber. Understanding the pathways that enable proteins to aggregate into particular structures may help reveal the nature of certain human diseases. The behavior of the solutions will be used to create simple demonstration devices as part of an educational outreach effort.

Cations and anions in aqueous solvent may interact with each other or with charged groups on small molecules, Langmuir monolayers, and polymer chains. A variety of spectroscopies including infrared, Raman, and vibrational sum frequency generation will be used to investigate how contact pair, solvent shared, and solvent separated ion-ion interactions are affected by the size of the ions, their geometry, their hydrogen bonding ability, van der Waals forces, and the surrounding chemical environment. The molecular level details of these interactions will then be correlated with thermodynamic properties of the corresponding aqueous solutions to understand how ion pairing can influence macroscopic behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding the molecular level interactions of lipid-water, polymer-water and protein-water interfaces with ions. Both the macroscopic behavior of these systems and the interfacial water structure showed cation and anion specific effects. A major goal was to investigate specific binding motifs and changes in hydration structure that occurred as a results of ion-substrate interactions. A variety of spectroscopic techniques was employed in combination with thermodynamic measurements. The goal was to correlate changes in spectroscopic signatures with macroscopic changes to the systems, such as phase transitions. This approach led to several important findings. For example, it was shown that guanidinium cations can have a variety of influences on protein folding and aggregation depending on the nature of the counterion.  Protein structure was stabilized when sulfate was used as the anion. In this case, guanidinium was pulled away from the protein surface by the anion. On the other hand, the behavior with SCN- was markedly different. Both folded and unfolded structures could stabilized in different salt concentration ranges. This occurred because guanidinium partitioned to the surface with anion. Next, it was found that trimethylamine N-oxide, a powerful protein stabilizer, works by binding to the protein/water interfaces rather than being excluded from them. Moreover, the binding of weakly hydrated anions to polypeptides was shown to involve the hydrophobic portions of the macromolecule, while the amide NH moieties were less decisive in the binding process.

In addition to the findings made for protein-ion interactions, there were several important discoveries on the interactions of cations with lipid bilayers. For example, it was shown that Cu2+ interacts strongly with lipids containing free amine moieties like phosphatidylserine and phosphatidylethanolamine. Such interactions with copper ions are important because this is a redox active transition metal ion that can lead to lipid oxidation when an appropriate oxidant is also present. Furthermore, it was found that Mg2+ and Ca2+ have very different interactions with lipid bilayers containing phosphatidylinositol lipids. The difference stems from the fact that Ca2+ can shed its hydration shells and interact directly with phosphate groups on the lipids, while Mg2+ interactions involve sharing a water molecule. Because of this, Ca2+ is better able to dimerize lipid molecules than Mg2+. This difference is directly relevant in Ca2+ regulation inside cells.

An understanding of ion-polymer interactions in water was employed for expanding the high school chemistry curriculum. This involved designing new laboratories for 10th and 11th graders.  New hands-on experiments were put together to explore non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding, ion pairing, and hydrophobic interactions. Videos describing the chemistry of ion specific effects were made for high school students, which showed them how to measure phase transitions in the presence of different salts. These experiments were successfully implemented in the classroom.
